thread.title: Krill eyestalks key to understanding vital player in Antarctic ecosystem
thread.title_full: Krill eyestalks key to understanding vital player in Antarctic ecosystem

author: Harriet Aird
title: Krill eyestalks key to understanding vital player in Antarctic ecosystem
text:
Photo: Antarctic krill are the main food source for a plethora of sealife. (Supplied: Australian Antarctic Division) 
They have discovered that the crustaceans' eyestalks have tiny band markings that correspond with each year of the animal's life, much like the growth rings found in trees. 
Rob King, krill biologist at the Australian Antarctic Division (AAD) in Tasmania, said understanding the age of krill was critical. 
"As pressures mount on the krill population we need to be able to understand whether there's enough young krill coming through, and enough older krill to produce new recruits," he said. 
To test the validity of the growth bands, AAD scientists hatched and grew krill in their research aquarium in Kingston, south of Hobart. 
The same process was undertaken in Japan, but the krill were kept at a different water temperature. 
Those "control" krill were then compared to wild krill from Antarctica, which meant researchers could be certain that each growth band equalled a year of life. Photo: The age of krill cannot be determined using normal methods, Dr Kawaguchi said. (Supplied: Australian Antarctic Division) No krill means no whales, seals, penguins 
Researcher So Kawaguchi said the new method could inform climate research, as it allowed comparisons to be drawn between the current day and the early 1900s. Photo: Krill were flown from Antarctica to Hobart for research for the first time in 2016. (ABC News: Elise Fantin) 
"This research is not only applicable to the living krill, but also to the krill that have been preserved for hundreds of years," he said. 
The findings will help to inform the way krill stocks are managed, ensuring the species is not overfished. 
"At the moment, the krill fishery itself is not that big and is well managed by the international body," Dr Kawaguchi said. 
"Our role is to come up with the best available science, [which] can be used for [ocean fishing] management." 
Krill underpin the Antarctic ecosystem and play a key role in removing carbon dioxide from the Southern Ocean. 
"If you want to preserve the ecosystem of the animals most people associate with Antarctica, whales and seals and penguins, you must preserve their food. 
"[That means] preserving krill and the phytoplankton krill rely on," Mr King said. 
"[Krill and phytoplankton are] buying us surface living creatures more time on the planet." 
The study was undertaken in partnership with researchers in the United States, Canada and Japan.
